Recommendations for debugging algorithms
Creating algorithms is regularly accompanied by cases where the program code and the result of its execution are questionable and involve testing, checking, and debugging. Therefore, GreenData has built-in tools for
debugging
algorithms listed later in this article.
Debugging recommendations
Before using these tools, some basic organizational recommendations should be considered.
1.
Use the built-in debugging tools
.
The built-in tools of the algorithm editor can be used to execute the algorithm line by line. Algorithm execution can be stopped (interrupted) by the user.
2.
The algorithm must be compiled
.
The system allows saving the uncompiled code of an algorithm, but the algorithm is executed only after its compilation.
Do not try to save defective code of an algorithm containing obvious syntax errors. If the algorithm contains an incorrect (underwritten, incomplete) language construction, it is better to save this algorithm while commenting the problematic code section.
3.
Use single-line comments
.
Use single-line comments to:
add an author’s note above the following function with a non-obvious operator;
add an author’s note (on the right) on the line of the current operator;
comment the problematic operator or the uncompleted expression.
Examples of single-line comments.
4.
Use multi-line comments
.
Use multiline comments for:
adding a detailed textual explanation;
commenting several lines/problematic operators of the algorithm.
Examples of multi-line comments.
Debugging tools
1.
sendPopUpMsg
(for more details refer to the
sendPopUpMsg
article)
triggers a non-modal notification pop-up window;
is used to diagnose the triggering of algorithm branches;
designed to display scalar values (strings, numbers…​);
sendPopUpMsg cannot display data structures (arrays, ArrayList, HashSet, HashMap, etc.).
Examples of SendPopUpMsg.
2.
printout
(for more details refer to the
Data structures
)
is used to diagnose the triggering of an algorithm;
supports displaying
scalar
values and
data structures
;
printout examples.
3.
writeWfLog
is used for complex logging situations of business process algorithms;
does not display data, but saves them to the special table (wf_trace_log).
Conclusions
The technique of debugging problem algorithms involves:
framing the problematic code sections with comments;
Use of the universal printout function to monitor the variable values in the algorithm’s log;
modifying and changing the program code taking into account the monitoring data;
gradual reduction of the commented operators.
Although the described technique allows to diagnose and debug almost any algorithm, in debugging practice it will be useful to
sendPopUpMsg
to temporarily notify the user about the triggering of critical operators and branches of the algorithm.
